Avis: Amazing restaurant to eat at if you want to roam around the Eiffel Tower and Champ de Mars after dinner. The outdoor seating allows you to people watch and also gives you the opportunity to enjoy looking at the small street while you eat or drink. I personally preferred the indoor seating, as it felt more cozy inside. Our waiter immediately gave our party an English menu which was very attentive of him to do. He also spoke very good English, so communication was not an issue. I ordered the Flank Steak with the baked potato which was alright. The reason why I did not like it too much was because there was no salt or pepper on the steak, which made it a bit bland to eat. The meat was also tough to cut. I still rate this restaurant a 5/5 because all the other dishes were enjoyable, the atmosphere is pleasant for dinner, and the service was incredible. Another person in my party ordered the Sauteed Chicken marinated in coconut milk and curry, which was very delicious. I was skeptical at first because it is a Thai inspired dish; I did not have high expectations for it. The chicken was very tender and juicy, while the marinade was creamy but not too overpowering. Easily a 5/5. The third person in my party ordered the Wednesday special which was the Baked Pork Ribs. The meat came off the bone without any effort. We did not have to put pressure on the meat to get it off the bone. The sauce on the ribs was amazing and the meat was very soft and juicy. For dessert, we ordered the Creme Brulee which was phenomenal. The sugar on top of the custard was perfectly crunchy and hard. The custard had an amazing texture. I think this was the best creme brulee that I've had during my stay in Paris and I've had creme brulee everyday, at different cafes and restaurants. The only suggestion that I have is to use less vanilla bean or vanilla extract, as it was a tad overpowering in the custard. Besides this small issue, it was a perfect creme brulee. I was very impressed with my experience at this restaurant and I hope to pay a visit if I go to Paris again.

Avis: Le Petit Cler was one of my favorite restaurants in Paris - and quickly became one of my top favorite restaurants ever. My husband and I had bookmarked/starred Le Petit Cler as we started researching our trip to Paris. The pictures of the Croque Madame did my husband in, while I was mesmerized by the many offerings of tartines (and a great wine list), as well as the fact that Le Petit Cler is on Rue Cler, one of the cutest little streets in Paris. Our first visit to Le Petit Cler was for dinner - I asked for a table outside (in French), and my husband and I were brought two French menus, which gave my husband anxiety from the get-go because he can read about zero French. Our server came over after some time to take our order (again, just a reminder - this is not rudeness, they're allotting enough time for you to absorb the menu, so don't be surprised if you're sitting at a table for a bit prior to someone welcoming you/taking drink orders), and saw my husband on Yelp reading the English version the of the menu. We ordered a carafe of water as well as a bottle of the Roquefort Bordeaux (28 €), and requested a bit more time to order our meals. A new server came back, who promptly placed an English menu down for my husband and then (in English) asked if we were ready to order. My husband ordered the special plat of the day, the beef lasagna (there's a different special plate each day - all are printed on the menu for 13,5 €), and I ordered the warm goat cheese/tomato/endive tartine (14 €). We sipped our wine (delicious - highly recommend! until our food arrived. Not only was the plating absolutely gorgeous, but the food was incredible. Everything was perfectly seasoned, fresh, and filling - like the kind of meal where you're quiet because you're absolutely loving what you're eating. We finished our dinner, and then ordered a cheese plate (a Camembert and chevre), and my husband ordered the chocolat Petit Pot (literally a little jar of chocolate mousse - it was delicious). The service was amazing, the food incredible, and the ambiance so traditionally Parisian that we decided we needed to come back the next day for our final lunch in Paris. Our lunch the next day had some things in common with our first visit: a seat outside, the same bottle of Bordeaux, and amazing service. This time I ordered the tartine with raw salmon and cream cheese (17 €), and my husband ordered the Croque Madame (15 €) that he had lusted over via Yelp photos. It was a particularly hot day in Paris, and sitting in the sun during our lunch emboldened us to each order a bowl of Berthillon ice cream (vanilla for my husband, raspberry sorbet pour moi). It was delicious, and exactly what we needed on such a hot day. All in all, Le Petit Cler was the perfect Parisian experience - the food was delicious, the service wonderful, the ambiance absolutely perfect, and the people watching completely top notch. Cannot wait to return to Paris and come back to this wonderful restaurant.

Avis: Awesome place for dinner near the Eiffel Tower. On our first night in Paris, we decided to eat here due to good recommendations. The restaurant is very easy to find along the very popular pedestrian street Rue Cler. We were attended to immediately and sat near the back of the restaurant. The place itself is tiny so the "back" was literally 10 feet from the front entrance. We ordered a variety of typical French plates to share as our meal: escargots, tomato and mozzarella salad, cheese platter, and a foie gras board. Everything was great, especially the foie gras, so creamy and satisfying without being too pungent. The tomatoes were also very fresh and sweet. The escargots were a bit on the smaller size but still tasty. We ordered 2 cheeses for our board but you can request up to 4. They never told us what the cheeses were but we guessed that it was a brie and goat cheese. It also came with a slice of butter. And we had a glass of the recommended rose wine to go with our meal. The other amazing aspect of this place was the waiters. We were serviced by about 4 different guys and each one was extremely friendly and very attentive. They also spoke English very well which made the entire experience that much better. The only negative was how packed the place was. Luckily, we were seated by the wall so we had some privacy but we noticed that the other patrons were literally within 6 inches of the next table over. Had that been us, we wouldn't have had as great a time. We arrived around 7:30 and the restaurant was about one third full. However, when we left around 8:30, every table was packed to the point where even leaving was a struggle. The French are known to dine late in the evening so if you eat around 7:30 to 8:00, most places shouldntbe too packed just yet. Anyway, Le Petit Cler was an awesome experience for dinner on our first night back in Paris. Price- 70euros for: 2 glasses of rose, 6 escargots, cheese plate with 2 cheeses, tomato and mozzarella salad, foie gras (a bit pricy but the area is nice and upscale and it is Paris after all!)

Avis: Great attentive service. Everyone here on the staff spoke French and English I asked the server what they were known for/what's their customers' favorite dish. He pointed me to a grilled chicken with a sort of sweet glaze severed alongside a sweet baked potato and arugula salad. It was fresh simple and delicious. The baked potato NEEDED NOTHING, no salt, no butter, no seasoning , no sour cream and was one of the best baked potatoes I've had in my life. The shop is along a closed off street across from a fresh fruit stand which adds to local flavor and gives you more of a small town feel even in the heart of Paris. Price: I paid about 19 euros for my meal, water, earl grey tea and lemon cake. Which seemed more than fair. Crowd: Perfect for groups of 2-4. Larger parties may have issues being accommodated in the smaller more cozy layout. Highly recommend for food or even a few glasses of chilled champagne sitting out on the sidewalk. Le Petit Cler gets my vote.

Avis: The food was phenomenal. The staff was great. Wondering why four stars? Well, maybe it's me being an American, but the tables are so cramped together that you're just up in everyone's business and vice versa - I hate this. You literally can't move, and that just brings down any dining experience in my book. If you can get past this, stop by, really. They're friendly, fast, and the food is great. We had escargot, and an incredible Croque Madam (ham, cheese, and an egg) as starters. We split a flank steak and potatoes for the main dish, also very nice. Steak was a bit underdone, more rare than the medium rare we asked for, but great nonetheless.
